questions.text: A particular community population has been consuming Maize as a staple diet for years. The vitamin deficiency most likely to be seen in this population is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Niacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Maize as a staple diet leads to niacin deficiency due to its low tryptophan and high leucine content, resulting in pellagra.
  • ➤ Note – Leucine is known as pellagrogenic aminoacid in India
  • ➤ Note – Leucine is known as pellagrogenic aminoacid in India

questions.text: Which of the following investigations does not use antibody marking? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hemagglutination Test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hemagglutination test is unique in its use of direct interactions between particles (like viruses) and red blood cells to demonstrate binding and agglutination, distinguishing it from other tests that rely on labeled antibodies to indicate the presence of specific antigens or antibodies. This method is particularly useful in blood typing and viral detection.

questions.text: Mark the correct statement/s about Inner and Outer hair cells. (INICET Nov 2023) Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate function of inner hair cells Outer hair cells are more responsible for movement of tectorial membrane Inner hair cells are in single row and modulate function of outer hair cells Outer and inner hair cells are present in the ratio 3:1
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 5 are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct statements about inner and outer hair cells are that inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses, outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and help modulate cochlear mechanics, and the ratio of outer to inner hair cells is about 3:1.

questions.text: A girl presents with short stature, webbed neck, thick calves, shield -shaped chest, swelling of the ankle, and increased carrying angle. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Turner syndrome is characterized by features such as short stature, webbed neck, shield-shaped chest, peripheral lymphedema, and increased carrying angle, among other physical manifestations. It is caused by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome in phenotypic females.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations are not used for diagnosing osteoporosis?(INICET NOV 2020) DEXA Bone scan Quantitative CT Chemical analysis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DEXA scan is the investigation of choice. Quantitative CT is a bone mineral density (BMD) measurement technique in which the CT scanner is calibrated using solid phantoms (made of calcium hydroxyapatite, representing various bone mineral densities) placed under the patient in a pad. With this calibration, the Hounsfield units are converted to bone mineral density values. The technique can be used for both peripheral and central BMD measurements, with lumbar spine and hip being preferred locations. DEXA measures the bone mineral density of both the outer (cortical) shell and the inner (trabecular) structure of the bone. QCT, on the other hand, measures only the inner part. Because of this difference, QCT studies of the spine show a lower T-score than a DEXA would.
  • ➤ DEXA scan is the investigation of choice.
  • ➤ Quantitative CT is a bone mineral density (BMD) measurement technique in which the CT scanner is calibrated using solid phantoms (made of calcium hydroxyapatite, representing various bone mineral densities) placed under the patient in a pad. With this calibration, the Hounsfield units are converted to bone mineral density values. The technique can be used for both peripheral and central BMD measurements, with lumbar spine and hip being preferred locations.
  • ➤ DEXA measures the bone mineral density of both the outer (cortical) shell and the inner (trabecular) structure of the bone. QCT, on the other hand, measures only the inner part. Because of this difference, QCT studies of the spine show a lower T-score than a DEXA would.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with a white pupillary reflex for which enucleation was done. The histopathological examination of the specimen showed Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the most likely diagnosis? ( NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Retinoblastoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes are a hallmark of retinoblastoma, indicating a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells. This specific histopathological finding is crucial for diagnosing retinoblastoma, especially in children presenting with leukocoria.
  • ➤ Different rosettes seen in retinoblastoma:
  • ➤ Different rosettes seen in retinoblastoma:
  • ➤ 1. True rosette -FLEXNER-WINTERSTEINER ROSETTE
  • ➤ This is specific for RB - hallmark of RB It consists of tumor cells surrounding a central lumen that contains cytoplasmic extensions from the tumor cells, which have well-differentiated features suggestive of primitive photoreceptor cells.
  • ➤ This is specific for RB - hallmark of RB
  • ➤ It consists of tumor cells surrounding a central lumen that contains cytoplasmic extensions from the tumor cells, which have well-differentiated features suggestive of primitive photoreceptor cells.
  • ➤ 2. HOMER-WRIGHT ROSETTE is a non-specific rosette seen in any of the primitive neuroectodermal tumors. Tumor cells surround a central region containing neutrophil.
  • ➤ 3. FLUERETTE is pseudo rosette because the central structure is not a part of the tumor and it consists of tumor cells around a blood vessel.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman experiences a 2-year history of infertility, as well as experiencing dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea. She has a retroverted uterus and is sensitive in the Douglas pouch. What should be the subsequent course of action in her management? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) TVS

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first step in the management of suspected endometriosis is to perform transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) to evaluate pelvic structures and identify abnormalities.

questions.text: An investigation was conducted to evaluate the nutritional status of young children residing in both rural and urban regions. Among the participants, 30 children from rural areas and 20 children from urban areas were found to be malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chi Square test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Chi Square test is the appropriate statistical test for evaluating the association between two categorical variables, such as nutritional status (malnourished vs. not malnourished) and location (rural vs. urban).

questions.text: A woman has vomiting whenever she eats spicy food. Arrange the sequence of events during vomiting? (INICET MAY 2022) LES is open and UES is closed. Strong contractions in the stomach. Inspiration against a closed glottis. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter. LES opens and UES opens. Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine. LES: Lower esophageal sphincter UES: Upper esophageal sphincter
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 6, 4, 2, 3, 1, 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sequence of events in act of vomiting:
  • ➤ Sequence of events in act of vomiting:
  • ➤ Beginning of antiperistalsis, which runs from ileum towards the mouth through the intestine, pushing the intestinal contents into the stomach within few minutes. Velocity of the antiperistalsis is about 2 to 3 cm/second Deep inspiration followed by temporary cessation of breathing Closure of glottis Upward and forward movement of larynx and hyoid bone Elevation of soft palate Contraction of diaphragm and abdominal muscles with a characteristic jerk, resulting in elevation of intra-abdominal pressure Compression of the stomach between diaphragm and abdominal wall leading to rise in intragastric pressure Simultaneous relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter, esophagus and upper esophageal sphincter Forceful expulsion of gastric contents (vomitus) through esophagus, pharynx and mouth.
  • ➤ Beginning of antiperistalsis, which runs from ileum towards the mouth through the intestine, pushing the intestinal contents into the stomach within few minutes. Velocity of the antiperistalsis is about 2 to 3 cm/second
  • ➤ Deep inspiration followed by temporary cessation of breathing
  • ➤ Closure of glottis
  • ➤ Upward and forward movement of larynx and hyoid bone
  • ➤ Elevation of soft palate
  • ➤ Contraction of diaphragm and abdominal muscles with a characteristic jerk, resulting in elevation of intra-abdominal pressure
  • ➤ Compression of the stomach between diaphragm and abdominal wall leading to rise in intragastric pressure
  • ➤ Simultaneous relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter, esophagus and upper esophageal sphincter
  • ➤ Forceful expulsion of gastric contents (vomitus) through esophagus, pharynx and mouth.

questions.text: A female patient presented with symptomatic urinary symptoms. On laboratory examination, growth of coagulase negative novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with >10⁴ colony growth is seen. What is the true statement regarding this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.correct_answer: D. Consider it as a UTI
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Consider it as a UTI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a female patient presents with symptomatic urinary symptoms and lab findings show coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with significant colony growth, it should be considered as a UTI and treated accordingly.

questions.text: A mother delivers in a rural area under the guidance of a skilled birth attendant. Incorrect regarding the care provided by the skilled birth attendant is: (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Start breastfeeding as soon as possible

options.label: B
options.text: Clear eyes with a sterile swab

options.label: C
options.text: Bath to newborn with warm water

questions.correct_answer: C. Bath to newborn with warm water
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bath to newborn with warm water

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Newborns should not be bathed immediately after birth to prevent hypothermia; instead, they should be wiped clean and kept warm by wrapping them appropriately.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication to given drug? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Malpresentation of fetus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given drug in the image is Oxytocin, which is commonly used to induce or augment labor. However, its use is contraindicated in several conditions to avoid complications during childbirth. One such contraindication is malpresentation of the fetus, where the fetus is not in a head-down position, potentially complicating a vaginal delivery.
  • • Contraindications to Oxytocin:
  • • Contraindications to Oxytocin:
  • • Grand multipara: Women who have given birth five or more times. Contracted pelvis: A pelvis that is too small to allow the passage of the fetus. History of Classical Cesarean Section: Classical C-sections involve a vertical incision in the uterus, increasing the risk of uterine rupture. History of 2 or more Lower Segment Cesarean Sections (LSCS): Multiple C-sections also increase the risk of uterine rupture. Malpresentation: Includes breech, transverse, or any non-cephalic presentation of the fetus. Obstructed labor: Labor that does not progress due to physical obstruction. Fetal distress: Signs that the fetus is not well, such as abnormal heart rate patterns. Hypovolemia: Reduced blood volume in the mother, which can complicate the use of oxytocin.
  • • Grand multipara: Women who have given birth five or more times.
  • • Grand multipara:
  • • Contracted pelvis: A pelvis that is too small to allow the passage of the fetus.
  • • Contracted pelvis:
  • • History of Classical Cesarean Section: Classical C-sections involve a vertical incision in the uterus, increasing the risk of uterine rupture.
  • • History of Classical Cesarean Section:
  • • History of 2 or more Lower Segment Cesarean Sections (LSCS): Multiple C-sections also increase the risk of uterine rupture.
  • • History of 2 or more Lower Segment Cesarean Sections (LSCS):
  • • Malpresentation: Includes breech, transverse, or any non-cephalic presentation of the fetus.
  • • Malpresentation:
  • • Obstructed labor: Labor that does not progress due to physical obstruction.
  • • Obstructed labor:
  • • Fetal distress: Signs that the fetus is not well, such as abnormal heart rate patterns.
  • • Fetal distress:
  • • Hypovolemia: Reduced blood volume in the mother, which can complicate the use of oxytocin.
  • • Hypovolemia:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Heart disease in mother : Heart disease in the mother is considered a relative contraindication for oxytocin administration. It requires careful monitoring and assessment by the healthcare provider, but it is not an absolute contraindication.
  • • Option B. Heart disease in mother
  • • Option C. Premature labour : Oxytocin can sometimes be used to manage labor in preterm situations under strict medical supervision. It is not an absolute contraindication.
  • • Option C. Premature labour
  • • Option D. Hypothyroidism : Hypothyroidism is not a contraindication for the use of oxytocin. Proper management of hypothyroidism is necessary during pregnancy, but it does not specifically preclude the use of oxytocin.
  • • Option D. Hypothyroidism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oxytocin is contraindicated in malpresentation of the fetus, grand multipara, contracted pelvis, history of classical cesarean, history of 2 or more LSCS, obstructed labor, fetal distress, and hypovolemia.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 573, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 226 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 573, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 226 th edition

questions.text: Va/Q = infinity means? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Partial pressure of O 2 becomes zero

options.label: C
options.text: CO 2 alone equilibrates with the venous blood

options.label: D
options.text: Partial pressure of both CO 2 and O 2 remain normal

questions.correct_answer: B. No exchange of O 2 & CO 2
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. No exchange of O2& CO2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • In quantitative terms, the ventilation-perfusion ratio is expressed as Va/Q. When Va (alveolar ventilation) is normal for a given alveolus and Q (blood flow) is also normal for the same alveolus, the ventilation-perfusion ratio (Va/Q) is also said to be normal.
  • • This ratio explains the respiratory exchange when there is an imbalance between alveolar ventilation and alveolar blood flow When the ventilation (Va) is zero, yet there is still perfusion (Q) of the alveolus, the Va/Q is zero. When there is adequate ventilation (Va) but zero perfusion (Q), the ratio Va/Q is infinity. At a ratio of either zero or infinity, there is no exchange of gases through the respiratory membrane of the affected alveoli.
  • • This ratio explains the respiratory exchange when there is an imbalance between alveolar ventilation and alveolar blood flow
  • • When the ventilation (Va) is zero, yet there is still perfusion (Q) of the alveolus, the Va/Q is zero.
  • • When there is adequate ventilation (Va) but zero perfusion (Q), the ratio Va/Q is infinity.
  • • At a ratio of either zero or infinity, there is no exchange of gases through the respiratory membrane of the affected alveoli.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Partial pressure of O2 becomes zero : Incorrect as partial pressure of O2 will be high in the alveoli but without perfusion, no exchange occurs.
  • • Option A. Partial pressure of O2 becomes zero
  • • Option C. CO2 alone equilibrates with the venous blood : Incorrect because without perfusion, there's no blood flow to equilibrate CO2 levels.
  • • Option C. CO2 alone equilibrates with the venous blood
  • • Option D. Partial pressure of both CO2 and O2 remain normal : Incorrect because, although the partial pressures in the ventilated alveoli might appear normal or even high for O2, without perfusion, these gases are not effectively exchanged with the blood.
  • • Option D. Partial pressure of both CO2 and O2 remain normal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A ventilation-perfusion (Va/Q) ratio of infinity, indicative of ventilation without perfusion, results in no exchange of oxygen (O2) and carbon dioxide (CO2) due to the absence of blood flow to the ventilated alveoli. This scenario highlights the critical balance needed between air delivery to the lungs and blood flow through the pulmonary circulation for effective respiratory gas exchange.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus is being evaluated for medications to manage their condition and prevent renal complications. Which of the following drugs will not delay progression of renal disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hydrochlorothiazide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydrochlorothiazide does not delay the progression of renal disease in patients with type 2 diabetes. In contrast, SGLT2 inhibitors, finerenone, and angiotensin receptor blockers are all known to provide renal protection and slow the progression of diabetic kidney disease.

questions.text: A person died suddenly whose family is abroad. A preservative was used to preserve his viscera. Which of the following poisoning is seen in it? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aconite

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aconite is a potent cardiac poison known for causing sudden death due to its severe impact on cardiac function
  • ➤ Cardiac poisons : Mnemonic - DHONAQ
  • ➤ Cardiac poisons
  • ➤ Mnemonic - DHONAQ
  • ➤ D igitalis, H ydrogen cyanide, O leander, N icotine, A conite, and Q uinine.
  • ➤ D
  • ➤ H
  • ➤ O
  • ➤ N
  • ➤ A
  • ➤ Q

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in a patient having a ↓ MCV, ↓ MCH, ↓ transferrin saturation, ↓ serum ferritin, and ↑ Total iron binding capacity? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Iron deficiency anemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Iron deficiency anemia is identified by microcytic hypochromic anemia with low serum ferritin, low transferrin saturation, and high TIBC, reflecting the body’s response to insufficient iron availability for hemoglobin synthesis.

questions.text: A skin rash gets exaggerated on sun exposure is repaired by which mechanism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Nucleotide excision repair

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nucleotide excision repair is the primary DNA repair mechanism that corrects damage caused by UV light, such as thymidine dimers.

questions.text: Cherry red spot without organomegaly is seen in which of the following disorders? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tay-Sachs disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by the presence of a cherry red spot in the retina without organomegaly.
  • ➤ Niemann-Pick disease - characterized by the presence of a cherry red spot in the retina with splenomegaly.

questions.text: What is the proportion of disease occurrence among those who were exposed compared to those who were not exposed? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Relative risk

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Relative Risk (RISK RATIO) is used to estimate risk of disease (calculated as incidence of that disease) with exposure to a factor Relative risk (RR) IS A BETTER ESTIMATE of strength of association than Attributable risk (AR) Strength of association: Relative risk (cohort study) Odds ratio (case control study)

  • ➤ Strength of association: Relative risk (cohort study) Odds ratio (case control study)

  • ➤ Odds ratio (case control study)

questions.text: A patient with chronic diarrhea develops dermatitis herpetiformis. The physician altered his diet which improved his symptoms. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Celiac disease should be suspected in patients presenting with chronic diarrhea and dermatitis herpetiformis, particularly when symptoms improve following a gluten-free diet.

questions.text: Identify the type of marked chromosome in the given karyotype? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acrocentric

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The marked chromosome is chromosome 13 and the type is acrocentric.
  • • Each chromatid has a long arm “q” and a short arm “p” which are separated by a centromere.
  • • Each chromatid has a long arm “q” and a short arm “p”
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Metacentric: Metacentric chromosomes have the centromere located in the center, creating arms of equal length. Examples include chromosomes 1 and 3.
  • • Option B. Metacentric:
  • • Option C. Submetacentric: Submetacentric chromosomes have the centromere slightly off-center, creating one long arm and one short arm. Most human autosomes and the X chromosome are submetacentric.
  • • Option C. Submetacentric:
  • • Option D. Telocentric: Telocentric chromosomes have the centromere at the very end of the chromosome, creating only one arm. This type is not present in humans.
  • • Option D. Telocentric:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Chromosomes are classified based on the position of the centromere as follows:
  • ➤ Chromosomes are classified based on the position of the centromere as follows:

questions.text: A 25-year-old male having pain and deformity of the tibia as shown in X-ray. He had history of trauma 2 years back. What is the most probable diagnosis?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chronic osteomyelitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The radiological image shown in the question and the clinical symptoms described are suggestive of chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A patient had features of resting tremors, bradykinesia, and postural instability. He became bedridden and died due to respiratory failure. Brain biopsy is likely to show which of the following? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lewy bodies

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical features described (resting tremors, bradykinesia, and postural instability) are characteristic of Parkinson's disease.
  • • In Parkinson's disease, the brain biopsy is likely to show Lewy bodies. Lewy bodies are intraneuronal, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies made of aggregates of alpha-synuclein.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Hirano bodies: Seen in Alzheimer's disease and other conditions like Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.
  • • Option B. Hirano bodies:
  • • Alzheimer's disease
  • • Option C. Guarnieri bodies: (Type B inclusion) Found in cells infected with poxvirus.
  • • Option C. Guarnieri bodies: (Type B inclusion)
  • • poxvirus.
  • • Option D. Negri bodies: Seen in the neurons of patients with rabies.
  • • Option D. Negri bodies:
  • • rabies.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Parkinson's disease, brain biopsies typically reveal Lewy bodies , which are intraneuronal, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies made of alpha-synuclein.
  • ➤ Lewy bodies
  • ➤ intraneuronal, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies
  • ➤ alpha-synuclein.

questions.text: An image of a perianal disease is shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Fistula in Ano

questions.text: What is the most sensitive investigation for parathyroid tumor imaging? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tc Sestamibi SPECT

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • For the imaging of parathyroid tumors, particularly in the context of hyperparathyroidism, several modalities can be employed. Each has its strengths and particular clinical situations where it might be the preferred choice.
  • • Tc Sestamibi SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography technique also utilizes Technetium-99m sestamibi but combines it with CT imaging to provide three-dimensional imaging. This makes SPECT more sensitive than a plain sestamibi scan for locating parathyroid tumors, especially when they are ectopic or embedded deep within the neck or chest.
  • • Tc Sestamibi SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Tc Sestamibi Scan : This is a nuclear medicine scan that uses a small amount of a radioactive compound , typically Technetium-99m sestamibi, which is absorbed by active parathyroid tissue more than normal tissue. While sensitive, it provides a two-dimensional view which can sometimes make precise localization of smaller or deeper tumors challenging.
  • • Option A. Tc Sestamibi Scan
  • • Option C. USG (Ultrasound): Ultrasound is useful for imaging the parathyroid glands due to its non-invasive nature and ability to detect lesions in real-time. It is particularly effective for glands located in typical positions near the thyroid. However, its effectiveness diminishes for ectopic glands or in obese patients where acoustic windows may be poor.
  • • Option C. USG (Ultrasound):
  • • Option D. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): MRI can provide detailed images and is useful in complex cases, such as when other imaging modalities fail or in surgical planning. However, its sensitivity is generally lower than Sestamibi SPECT for detecting parathyroid adenomas, and it is less commonly used primarily due to higher costs and limited availability.
  • • Option D. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Tc Sestamibi SPECT is generally considered the most sensitive imaging modality for detecting parathyroid tumors, particularly because it offers three-dimensional localization capabilities that can greatly assist surgeons in planning minimally invasive surgery.

questions.text: You are a researcher aiming to compile and analyze data from various independent studies to enhance the precision of treatment effect estimates for a specific medical condition. Which of the following methodologies is most appropriate for achieving this objective? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Meta-analysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Meta-analysis is the most effective quantitative approach for synthesizing data from multiple research studies to derive a more precise estimate of the treatment effect. Preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality - 1st preference is - Meta-analysis
  • ➤ Meta-analysis is the most effective quantitative approach for synthesizing data from multiple research studies to derive a more precise estimate of the treatment effect.
  • ➤ Preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality - 1st preference is - Meta-analysis

questions.text: A clinician is attending to several patients with different conditions in a hospital setting. Which of the following diseases necessitates placing the patient in a separate isolation room due to its airborne transmission risk? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Measles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Measles necessitates isolation in an airborne infection isolation room due to its high potential for airborne transmission, making it critical to prevent its spread in healthcare settings.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with symptoms of an inguinal hernia. During the operation, the surgeon observes a segment of necrotic bowel in the hernial sac. What is the appropriate course of action for resection and anastomosis of a necrotic bowel seen during surgery? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: The surgeon must use chromic catgut.

options.label: B
options.text: The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures.

options.label: C
options.text: The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.

options.label: D
options.text: The surgeon must use the single- layer seromuscular suture technique.

questions.correct_answer: C. The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The single-layer extramucosal suture technique is the preferred method in small bowel anastomosis to reduce complications such as bleeding, strictures, and anastomotic leaks.

questions.text: A patient presents in OPD with a history of fever and cough for 5 days. On auscultation, crepts were heard on right side. Chest X-ray is given below. Mark the correct finding in this case? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Apical segment of Right lower lobe consolidation

options.label: C
options.text: Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Right middle lobe consolidation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Right middle lobe consolidation is suggested by the obscuration of the right heart border and the specific location of opacity on the chest X-ray, aligned with the patient's clinical presentation of respiratory symptoms. This finding is crucial for diagnosing the specific location of pneumonia, guiding appropriate treatment.

questions.text: A patient with 12 weeks amenorrhea presents with vaginal bleeding. On examination, the cervical os is open and the uterus is 14 weeks size. USG shows a snowstorm appearance. The next best step in the management is? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Suction and evacuation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The snowstorm appearance on ultrasound is characteristic of a complete molar pregnancy (hydatidiform mole). Molar pregnancies are abnormal pregnancies where there is an overgrowth of trophoblastic tissue.
  • • Key Points:
  • • Key Points:
  • • Complete Molar Pregnancy: Presents with vaginal bleeding, an enlarged uterus greater than expected for gestational age, and a snowstorm appearance on ultrasound. Treatment: The primary treatment for a molar pregnancy is suction and evacuation to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue. Post-Evacuation Surveillance: After evacuation, it is crucial to monitor beta-hCG levels to ensure complete removal of the molar tissue and to detect any possible malignancy (e.g., choriocarcinoma).
  • • Complete Molar Pregnancy: Presents with vaginal bleeding, an enlarged uterus greater than expected for gestational age, and a snowstorm appearance on ultrasound.
  • • Complete Molar Pregnancy:
  • • Treatment: The primary treatment for a molar pregnancy is suction and evacuation to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue.
  • • Treatment:
  • • Post-Evacuation Surveillance: After evacuation, it is crucial to monitor beta-hCG levels to ensure complete removal of the molar tissue and to detect any possible malignancy (e.g., choriocarcinoma).
  • • Post-Evacuation Surveillance:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Medical management: Medical management is not appropriate for molar pregnancy, as surgical evacuation is necessary.
  • • Option A. Medical management:
  • • Option B. Follow up with beta-hCG: Beta-hCG monitoring is essential after the initial treatment but not before the evacuation of the molar tissue.
  • • Option B. Follow up with beta-hCG:
  • • Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is not the first line of treatment for a molar pregnancy unless there are specific complications or risk factors warranting such an invasive procedure.
  • • Option D. Hysterectomy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The management of a molar pregnancy involves suction and evacuation to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue, followed by post-evacuation surveillance with beta-hCG levels to monitor for persistent gestational trophoblastic disease or malignancy.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s Textbook of obstetrics 26 th edition pg 614
  • ➤ Ref: William’s Textbook of obstetrics 26 th edition pg 614

questions.text: What is the fixative used for a pap smear? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 95% ethanol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fixative used for a Pap smear is typically 95% ethanol, which helps preserve the cellular details on the slides for accurate cytological examination.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition 632, 633
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition 632, 633

questions.text: A 40-year-old Type 2 diabetic patient presents with fever and hypotension to the casualty. He gives a history of a boil in the perianal area which developed 2 weeks ago. On examination, the perianal area is as shown in the picture below. Identify the correct statement about this condition? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: It is caused by staphylococcus only

options.label: D
options.text: It is a case of testicular torsion

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The testis remains unaffected

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fournier's gangrene is a severe necrotizing infection of the perineal and genital regions, often sparing deeper structures like the testes. Immediate surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics are critical for management.

questions.text: Identify the anti-apoptotic factor among the following: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bcl-2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bcl-2's anti-apoptotic properties make it a key player in cellular survival and stress response. Its ability to inhibit key steps in the apoptotic process distinguishes it from other proteins like P-53, K-ras, and BAK, which have different roles in the regulation of cell death and proliferation.

questions.text: Identify the 2nd generation supraglottic airway device from the options given below. (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) LMA Proseal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ LMA Proseal is a second-generation supraglottic airway device, identified by its two-tube system that enhances safety by reducing the risk of aspiration

questions.text: A woman is planned for a laparoscopic hysterectomy. She asks the surgeon for any disadvantages of this procedure. What is the disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

questions.correct_answer: B. Not knowing the extent of thermal burns
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery is not knowing the extent of thermal burns.

questions.text: Fever occurs during inflammation due to all except: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Histamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Histamine is involved in mediating the local vascular effects of inflammation and not in the fever response, which is primarily driven by IL-1, TNF, and prostaglandins.

questions.text: Which bacterial toxin acts by interfering with EF-2 function? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Diphtheria

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylating elongation factor 2 (EF-2), blocking its function.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Clostridium : Produces toxins, but they do not target EF-2.
  • • Option B. Clostridium
  • • Option C. Bacillus : Associated with different toxins not affecting EF-2.
  • • Option C. Bacillus
  • • Option D. Vibrio : Known for cholera toxin affecting intestinal secretion, not EF-2.
  • • Option D. Vibrio

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diphtheria toxin uniquely targets EF-2, crucial for understanding its mechanism of action in causing disease by inhibiting protein synthesis.
